Question 48) They say that Humboldt, a nineteenth-century naturalist, amazed at geography, flora and fauna of the South American region, saw their inhabitants as if they were beggars sitting on a gold bag, referring to their immeasurable unresolved natural riches. Somehow, the scientist ratified our role of exporters of a nature in what would be the world after Iberian colonization: he saw us as territories condemned to take advantage of existing natural resources.
ACOSTA, A. Well live: an opportunity to imagine other worlds. The relationship between human being and nature highlighted in the text reflected the permanence of the following philosophical current:
A) Cognitive relativism.
B) dialectical materialism.
C) Cartesian rationalism.
D) Epistemological pluralism.
E) phenomenological existentialism.
